name: 4-nhac-2266-tetrame-piperidin-n-oxide
Reason: 4-Nhac-2266-tetrame-piperidin-n-oxide has a complex structure with multiple functional groups that can influence its melting point. Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The piperidine ring introduces rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20 °C. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to the reduced molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around -10 °C. The oxo group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10 °C. The presence of four methyl groups can also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +20 °C per group, totaling +80 °C. The nitro group introduces a significant dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50 °C. The carbonyl group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40 °C. The presence of four methoxy groups can also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +20 °C per group, totaling +80 °C. The oxime group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10 °C. The presence of four ether linkages can also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +20 °C per group, totaling +80 °C.
